p: HIV-1 B CAR sequences from Haiti ( n = 103) and the Dominican Republic ( n = 123) were finally used to reconstruct the demographic history of this viral epidemic in Hispaniola. Reconstruction of population dynamics with the BSKL coalescent-based model suggested that the B CAR epidemic in Hispaniola experienced an initial phase of fast exponential growth until the beginning of the 1990s, followed by a stabilization of the Ne ( Figure 3A). The BSKG model, however, supported a longer exponential growth phase until the late 1990s, followed by an epidemic decline that extended until the most recent coalescent event around the mid-2000s ( Figure 3B). The UNAIDS epidemiological data, in agreement with the BSKG model, indicate a growth in the number of new HIV infections in Hispaniola until the early 2000s and a subsequent phase of decline extending until the most recent date ( Figure 3C). To estimate the growth rate of the B CAR epidemic at the initial phase, three parametric coalescent models (logistic, exponential, and expansion) were compared. According to the best-fit logistic growth coalescent model ( Supplementary Table S7), the mean growth rate of the B CAR epidemic during the first decades of expansion in Hispaniola was 0.50 (95% HPD: 0.37â€“0.65).
